subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: Dr. Hastings Kamuzu Banda was the first President of Malawi and a prominent figure in the country’s struggle for independence.
points: Born in 1898 in Malawi (then Nyasaland).
Educated abroad in the United States and the United Kingdom.
Returned to lead Malawi to independence in 1964.

subsections.title: Role in Independence
subsections.content: Banda played a key role in ending British colonial rule in Malawi.
points: Led the Malawi Congress Party (MCP).
Mobilized mass support through political activism.
Negotiated with British authorities for self-governance.

subsections.title: Presidency
subsections.content: Banda became Malawi’s first Prime Minister and later its first President.
points: Ruled Malawi from 1964 to 1994.
Established a one-party state with the MCP as the only legal party.
Focused on modernization, healthcare, and education.
Maintained strict control over political opposition.

subsections.title: Legacy
subsections.content: Kamuzu Banda’s leadership left a complex legacy.
points: Remembered for uniting Malawi and promoting development.
Criticized for authoritarian rule and human rights abuses.
Influenced Malawi’s political and social structures significantly.

subsections.title: Death
subsections.content: Banda died in 1997 after retiring from politics.
points: Passed away in Malawi.
Left behind a nation shaped by his vision and policies.
Commemorated through monuments and national holidays.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: Bakili Muluzi is a prominent Malawian politician who served as the second President of Malawi after independence.
points: Born in 1943 in Malawi.
Leader of the United Democratic Front (UDF).
First democratically elected president in Malawi’s multi-party era.

subsections.title: Political Career
subsections.content: Muluzi played a key role in Malawi’s transition to multi-party democracy.
points: Became president in 1994, ending Kamuzu Banda’s 30-year rule.
Promoted political reforms and democratic governance.
Focused on economic liberalization and modernization.

subsections.title: Achievements as President
subsections.content: During his presidency, Muluzi made significant contributions to Malawi’s development.
points: Improved education and healthcare systems.
Encouraged private sector growth and foreign investment.
Worked to improve infrastructure and social services.

subsections.title: Challenges and Controversies
subsections.content: Muluzi’s leadership faced criticism and challenges.
points: Accusations of corruption and nepotism.
Political tensions with opposition parties.
Economic difficulties including poverty and unemployment.

subsections.title: Legacy
subsections.content: Bakili Muluzi’s presidency marked a significant era in Malawi’s political history.
points: Helped establish Malawi’s multi-party democracy.
Left a mixed legacy of reform and controversy.
Remains an influential figure in Malawian politics.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: Bingu wa Mutharika was the third President of Malawi, known for his focus on economic development and agricultural reforms.
points: Born in 1934 in Malawi.
Economist by training with education from India and the United States.
Served as president from 2004 until his death in 2012.

subsections.title: Political Career
subsections.content: Mutharika played a significant role in Malawi’s politics, both before and during his presidency.
points: Initially served as Minister of Economic Planning and Development.
Elected president in 2004 under the United Democratic Front (UDF).
Later formed the Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) and was re-elected in 2009.

subsections.title: Achievements as President
subsections.content: His administration focused on economic growth and agricultural productivity.
points: Implemented the Farm Input Subsidy Program boosting food security.
Promoted infrastructure development including roads and energy.
Encouraged macroeconomic stability and growth.

subsections.title: Challenges and Criticisms
subsections.content: Mutharika’s presidency faced political and social challenges.
points: Accused of authoritarian tendencies and restricting press freedom.
Faced protests over governance and economic issues.
Criticized for handling of corruption allegations.

subsections.title: Legacy
subsections.content: Bingu wa Mutharika left a mixed legacy in Malawi’s history.
points: Remembered for improving agricultural output and economic policies.
Criticized for political repression and human rights concerns.
His death in 2012 marked a significant transition in Malawi’s leadership.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: Joyce Banda is a Malawian politician who served as the first female President of Malawi, known for her focus on women's rights and economic reform.
points: Born in 1950 in Malawi.
First female President of Malawi, serving from 2012 to 2014.
Advocate for gender equality and social development.

subsections.title: Political Career
subsections.content: Banda has had a long and influential career in Malawian politics.
points: Served as Minister of Gender, Child Welfare and Community Services.
Vice President from 2009 until 2012.
Assumed presidency following the death of Bingu wa Mutharika.

subsections.title: Achievements as President
subsections.content: During her presidency, Joyce Banda initiated several reforms and development programs.
points: Promoted economic recovery and growth.
Focused on education, health, and women's empowerment.
Improved diplomatic relations and transparency.

subsections.title: Challenges
subsections.content: Her leadership faced political opposition and economic challenges.
points: Dealt with economic crises including fuel shortages and inflation.
Faced criticism from political opponents.
Worked to strengthen democratic institutions.

subsections.title: Legacy
subsections.content: Joyce Banda is remembered for breaking gender barriers and her contributions to Malawi's development.
points: First woman to lead Malawi as President.
Advocate for human rights and gender equality.
Continues to influence Malawian and African politics.

subsections.title: Location of the Mwenemutapa Kingdom
subsections.content: The Mwenemutapa Kingdom was located in Central Africa, specifically between the Limpopo and Zambezi Rivers.
points: Covered parts of present-day Zimbabwe and Mozambique.

subsections.title: Origins of the Kingdom
subsections.content: The kingdom originated from the Karanga subgroup of the Shona people who migrated from the Katanga region in Zaire. They initially established Great Zimbabwe, a chiefdom and precursor to the Mwenemutapa Kingdom.
points: Great Zimbabwe was built between 1200–1300 AD as a centre of trade, religion, and political organisation.
It declined due to soil exhaustion, decline in gold trade, and shortage of salt.
Mutota moved north to establish the new Mwenemutapa Kingdom.

subsections.title: The Role of Great Zimbabwe – Key Facts
subsections.content: Great Zimbabwe played multiple important roles in the region before its decline.
points: Centre of trade: Controlled trade routes exchanging gold and ivory with coastal traders.
Religious centre: Site for religious rituals and worship.
Political capital: Seat of the king and centre of administration.
Architectural achievement: Known for massive stone walls built without mortar.
Decline factors: Soil exhaustion, reduced gold trade, shortage of salt.
Legacy: Its decline led to the establishment of the Mwenemutapa Kingdom by Mutota.

subsections.title: Factors Leading to the Expansion of the Mwenemutapa Kingdom
subsections.content: Several factors contributed to the growth and expansion of the kingdom.
points: Able leadership by Nyatsimba Mutota and son Matope.
Trade in gold and ivory through strategic trade routes to the east coast.
Fertile soil supporting agriculture and population growth.
Economic activities such as metalwork, pottery, and textiles.
Common religion - the Mwari cult united people spiritually and culturally.
Arab advice and trade links promoting control over gold trade.
Personal ambitions of leaders and demographic pressures.

subsections.title: Socio-Political Organisation of the Mwenemutapa Kingdom
subsections.content: The kingdom had a centralised political system with complex social structures and economic activities.

subsections.title: Political Organisation
subsections.content: The Mwenemutapa held supreme and divine power supported by a structured court and council.
points: Centralised government led by the King (Mwenemutapa).
Royal court with officials like chancellor, chamberlain, military commander.
Council of chiefs advised the king and governed provinces.
The Royal Fire symbolised unity and authority.
A standing army ensured stability and territorial expansion.

subsections.title: Social Organisation
subsections.content: The society was structured with religious beliefs and clan systems.
points: Divine kingship viewing the king as god-like.
Worship of Mwari and ancestral spirits such as Vadzimu, Mhondoro, and Chaminuka.
Priesthood (Masvikiro) acted as mediators between spirits and people.
Clan system organised by totems and extended families.
Division of labour based on gender and skill sets.

subsections.title: Economic Organisation
subsections.content: The kingdom’s economy was based on agriculture, trade, crafts, fishing, and hunting.
points: Agriculture involved cultivation and animal husbandry.
Trade focused on gold, ivory, and iron tools exports.
Crafts included pottery, weaving, and metalwork.
Fishing and hunting supplemented diet and economy.

subsections.title: Factors Leading to the Decline of the Mwenemutapa Kingdom
subsections.content: Multiple internal and external challenges caused the decline.
points: Portuguese interference with political manipulation and military invasions.
Power struggles including conflicts with the Rozwi dynasty.
Rebellions by subjugated states like Kiteve and Manyika ceasing tribute.
Civil wars caused by succession disputes.
Resource depletion including soil fertility, timber, and salt shortages.

topics.title: Pre-colonial Kingdoms in Central Africa: Maravi

subsections.title: Factors Leading to Formation
subsections.content: Key factors that contributed to the formation of pre-colonial kingdoms in Central Africa.
points: Iron smelting
Long distance trade
Introduction of new crops (e.g., maize by the Portuguese)
Migration of people
Good leadership and centralized administration
Abundance of resources in the settled areas

subsections.title: The Maravi Kingdom - Geographical Development
subsections.content: The Maravi Kingdom originated near Lake Malawi and expanded into parts of Malawi, Mozambique, and Zambia.
points: Originated on southwestern shores of Lake Malawi
Initially included districts like Salima, Dedza, Ntcheu, and Mangochi
Expanded to cover most parts of modern Malawi, Mozambique, and Zambia

subsections.title: The Proto-Chewa
subsections.content: The earliest inhabitants were Akafula (Pygmies), later displaced by Bantu iron-age settlers.
points: Akafula were Stone Age hunters and gatherers
Bantu people arrived around 1000 AD
Bantu used iron weapons to defeat Akafula
Formed clans; Banda clan became most influential

subsections.title: Factors for Bantu Migration into Central Africa
subsections.content: Various pressures caused Bantu migration into Central Africa.
points: Rapid population growth and shortage of land
Lack of fertile land
Wars causing chiefs to flee
Succession and inheritance disputes
Escaping punishment after failed rebellions
Slave trade
Social/domestic issues like witchcraft accusations
Desire to control trade

subsections.title: Origin and Meaning of the Word 'Maravi'
subsections.content: The name 'Maravi' was adopted after settling at Mankhamba with symbolic meanings.
points: Flames of bushfires from hunting and clearing land
Sunrise splashes reflected on Lake Malawi
Iron smelting fires constantly burning

subsections.title: Origin of the Maravi
subsections.content: Maravi migrated from Uluba in Katanga and established political and religious centers.
points: Came as clans; main ones Banda and Phiri
Leader Mazizi led migration into eastern Zambia
Successor Chinkhole adopted title Kalonga (meaning 'to unite')
Kalonga Chidzonzi migrated to Manthimba (Dedza)
Final settlement at southwestern tip of Lake Malawi

subsections.title: Important Places in the Maravi Kingdom
subsections.content: The kingdom had key political and religious centers.
points: Manthimba – Political headquarters
Mankhamba – Religious and ancestral worship center
Msinja – Shrine in Lilongwe served by rainmaker Makewana
Kaphirintiwa – Believed origin of humankind
Khulubvi – Religious site and home to Mbona cult

subsections.title: Reasons for Migration of the Maravi
subsections.content: The Maravi migrated seeking resources, peace, and fertile lands.
points: To find trade goods like ivory
To access iron farming tools
To escape internal family conflicts and wars
Looking for fertile lands for farming and grazing

subsections.title: Why the Proto-Chewa Accepted the Maravi
subsections.content: The Maravi’s governance, peace, and intermarriage led to acceptance by Proto-Chewa.
points: Well-organized, centralized government
Practiced agriculture and iron smelting
Known for being peace-loving
Knowledge of medicine and magic for healing and protection
Intermarriage between Phiri and Banda clans

subsections.title: Factors for the Rise and Growth of the Maravi Kingdom
subsections.content: Agriculture, governance, religion, trade, and military conquest fueled the kingdom’s growth.
points: Settled fertile lands producing millet, cassava, sorghum, and maize
Strong centralized control by Kalonga
Religion reinforcing unity via ancestor worship and cults
Trade in ivory, iron tools, salt, slaves with Arabs and Portuguese
Military expansion and alliances, especially under Kalonga Masula

subsections.title: Decentralisation in the Maravi Kingdom
subsections.content: Sub-chiefs governed provinces under Kalonga’s supreme rule.
points: Chimwala – Lilongwe
Mkanda – Mchinji
Kanyenda – Nkhotakota
Chulu, Mwase, Kaluluma – Kasungu
Changamire – Dedza
Kabunduli – Nkhatabay
Mpinganjira – Mangochi

subsections.title: Breakaway Chiefs
subsections.content: Some chiefs broke away forming independent states due to conflicts and ambitions.
points: Undi: claimed kingship, moved to Zambia, controlled Msinja shrine and trade; declined due to conflicts and invasions
Lundu: accused of witchcraft, expanded territory into Mozambique, controlled Mbona cult, defeated later
Kaphwiti: brother of Lundu, settled at Malawi wa Kaphwiti, referred to Mbona shrine

subsections.title: Social–Political Organisation of the Maravi Kingdom
subsections.content: Centralized state with a hierarchy under Kalonga supported by officials and religious authority.
points: Kalonga – Supreme ruler
Territorial Chiefs (Eni Dziko)
Tributary Chiefs (Aphungu or Mbiri)
Village Headmen (Eni Mudzi)
Court officials like Nyangu (advisor), Khombe (military commander), Mkomba (executioner), and others

subsections.title: Religion in the Maravi Kingdom
subsections.content: Religion played a key role in unity and governance, centered on ancestor worship and cults.
points: Creator god: Chauta / Chisumphi / Namalenga
Thunga as messenger of Chisumphi
Prayers for rain, fertility, hunting success
Annual bush burning in honor of Chinkhole’s spirit
Religion promoted unity and Kalonga’s authority

subsections.title: Factors for the Decline of the Maravi Kingdom
subsections.content: Internal weaknesses and external pressures led to the kingdom's decline.
points: Vast territory hard to control causing breakaways
Weak defense and no standing army
Succession disputes causing internal conflicts
Decentralisation giving too much autonomy to sub-chiefs
Civil wars weakening the kingdom
Portuguese bypassing Kalonga for trade
Growth of slave trade causing insecurity and depopulation
Invasions by Ngoni, Portuguese, and Arabs
British colonisation reduced Kalonga’s authority

subsections.title: Impact of the Maravi Kingdom on Indigenous People
subsections.content: The Maravi Kingdom influenced trade, politics, unity, and governance in the region.
points: Promoted trade between Portuguese and local groups (Tonga, Tavala, Nsenga)
Introduced European goods such as cloth, beads, and firearms
Formed a strong centralized political empire
Incorporated diverse groups under one kingdom promoting unity
Political model for other kingdoms and states

topics.title: Ivory and Slave Trade in East and Central Africa

subsections.title: Development of Ivory and Slave Trade
subsections.content: Slavery and ivory trading were practiced in East and Central Africa before foreign intervention, but greatly expanded with Arab and Portuguese involvement.
points: Slavery was initially localized and not for export.
Demand for ivory increased due to European industrial needs.
Decline in gold mining led to more focus on ivory trade.
Ivory was in high demand in Europe for items like piano keys and ornaments.
Elephants were abundant in areas like Lilongwe-Kasungu and Lake Chilwa.
Chiefs promoted ivory trade due to economic benefits.
Swahili-Arabs moved inland as coastal ivory sources diminished.
Slaves were increasingly used as porters for ivory.
French and Portuguese plantations needed slaves.
Zanzibar and Pemba plantations demanded more labor.
Major traders included Jumbe, Mlozi, and Tippu Tip.

subsections.title: Organisation of Ivory and Slave Trade
subsections.content: Trade evolved from coastal exchanges to deep interior involvement, involving local leaders, middlemen, and foreign traders.
points: Trade began with Africans delivering goods to the coast.
Swahili-Arabs and Portuguese later established inland trade routes.
Firearms were used in raids to capture slaves.
Chiefs played a role by raiding and collecting ivory as tribute.
Middlemen tribes included:
▪ Bisa – turned to slave trade after elephant numbers declined.
▪ Nyamwezi – active in Tanzania, traded with Swahili-Arabs.
▪ Bemba – engaged in slave trade due to poor soils and disease.
▪ Chikunda – raided communities on behalf of Portuguese.
▪ Yao – peaceful traders who later became raiders.
Slaves were chained in caravans and forced to carry ivory.
Sick or weak slaves were abandoned or killed during transport.

subsections.title: Impact of Ivory and Slave Trade on Indigenous People
subsections.content: The trade brought both development and destruction to local communities.
points: Positive impacts included:
▪ Growth of towns such as Karonga, Nkhotakota, and Mangochi.
▪ Introduction of crops like maize, cassava, and citrus fruits.
▪ Spread of religions like Christianity and Islam.
▪ Exposure to new cultures and goods.
▪ Encouragement of legitimate trade alternatives.
Negative impacts included:
▪ Depopulation due to frequent slave raids and violence.
▪ Destruction of traditional cultural systems.
▪ Famines caused by insecurity and inability to farm.
▪ Ecological damage from elephant overhunting.
▪ Spread of diseases like smallpox and syphilis.
▪ Colonization justified through anti-slavery campaigns.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: The Egyptian civilization is one of the world’s oldest and most influential ancient civilizations, known for its rich culture, monumental architecture, and contributions to human knowledge.
points: Located along the Nile River in northeastern Africa.
Developed around 3100 BCE with the unification of Upper and Lower Egypt.
Lasted for over 3,000 years until conquest by foreign powers.

subsections.title: Political Structure
subsections.content: Egyptian civilization was ruled by Pharaohs who were considered both kings and gods.
points: Pharaohs had absolute power and were central to government and religion.
A bureaucracy supported the Pharaohs, including officials, scribes, and priests.
The civilization was divided into nomes (provinces) governed by local officials.

subsections.title: Cultural Achievements
subsections.content: The Egyptians made significant advances in various fields.
points: Developed hieroglyphic writing system.
Built impressive monuments like the pyramids and the Sphinx.
Made advances in mathematics, astronomy, and medicine.
Created complex religious beliefs including gods, afterlife, and rituals.

subsections.title: Economy
subsections.content: Egypt’s economy was based on agriculture, trade, and labor.
points: Fertile land along the Nile allowed for productive farming of wheat, barley, and flax.
Trade networks extended to Africa, the Middle East, and the Mediterranean.
Craftsmanship in pottery, textiles, and jewelry contributed to economic life.

subsections.title: Religion and Beliefs
subsections.content: Religion played a central role in Egyptian life and governance.
points: Polytheistic belief system with gods like Ra, Osiris, Isis, and Anubis.
Belief in the afterlife and preservation of the body through mummification.
Temples served as religious and community centers.

subsections.title: Legacy
subsections.content: Egyptian civilization influenced later cultures and continues to captivate people today.
points: Contributions to art, architecture, and writing systems.
Influence on Greek and Roman civilizations.
Modern archaeological discoveries have deepened understanding of ancient history.

topics.title: Study of History, Sources, and Importance

subsections.title: Definition of History
subsections.content: History is the study of past events involving human activities, societies, and civilizations.
points: It helps us understand how societies have evolved over time.
Involves analyzing causes and effects of events.
Provides insights into cultural, political, and social developments.

subsections.title: Sources of History
subsections.content: Historians use various sources to gather information about the past.
points: Primary Sources: Original materials from the time period such as letters, official documents, artifacts, and eyewitness accounts.
Secondary Sources: Interpretations and analyses based on primary sources, including textbooks, articles, and documentaries.
Oral Traditions: Stories, songs, and verbal accounts passed down through generations.
Archaeological Evidence: Physical remains like buildings, tools, and fossils that provide clues about past societies.

subsections.title: Importance of Studying History
subsections.content: Studying history is vital for individuals and societies.
points: Helps us understand our identity and cultural heritage.
Provides lessons from past successes and mistakes.
Promotes critical thinking and informed decision making.
Encourages appreciation of diversity and different perspectives.
Supports citizenship by understanding rights, responsibilities, and governance.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: The Lomwe are one of the major ethnic groups in Malawi, with a rich cultural heritage and distinct traditions.
points: They primarily inhabit the southern region of Malawi.
Speak the Lomwe language, which is part of the Bantu language family.
Have a strong sense of community and cultural identity.

subsections.title: History and Origins
subsections.content: The Lomwe people trace their origins to migrations from Mozambique and Tanzania centuries ago.
points: Migrated into Malawi during the 19th century.
Settled mainly in Mulanje, Thyolo, and parts of Phalombe districts.
Maintained close cultural ties with Lomwe communities in Mozambique.

subsections.title: Culture and Traditions
subsections.content: The Lomwe have unique customs and social practices that define their way of life.
points: Strong emphasis on family and respect for elders.
Traditional dances and music play an important role in celebrations.
Practice initiation ceremonies for boys and girls.
Use of traditional herbal medicine is common.

subsections.title: Economic Activities
subsections.content: The Lomwe are primarily engaged in agriculture and trade.
points: Grow crops like tea, maize, cassava, and sweet potatoes.
Tea estates in the southern region provide employment.
Involved in small-scale trading and crafts.

subsections.title: Language and Communication
subsections.content: The Lomwe language is central to their identity and daily life.
points: It belongs to the Bantu group of languages.
Used in homes, markets, and traditional ceremonies.
Efforts are ongoing to preserve and promote the Lomwe language.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: Dr. David Livingstone was a Scottish missionary, explorer, and abolitionist renowned for his exploration of Africa in the 19th century.
points: Born in 1813 in Scotland.
Known for combining missionary work with geographic exploration.
Inspired global interest in Africa through his writings.

subsections.title: Explorations in Africa
subsections.content: Livingstone undertook extensive explorations across central and southern Africa.
points: First European to see the Victoria Falls in 1855.
Mapped vast areas of the continent previously unknown to Europeans.
Sought routes for trade and missions while combating the slave trade.

subsections.title: Missionary Work and Abolitionism
subsections.content: He was committed to spreading Christianity and fighting against slavery.
points: Established missions to promote education and Christianity.
Advocated for the abolition of the slave trade in Africa.
His travels helped expose the horrors of slavery to the world.

subsections.title: Legacy
subsections.content: Livingstone’s work left a lasting impact on exploration and humanitarian efforts.
points: Inspired further exploration and scientific research in Africa.
Remembered for his famous phrase ‘Dr. Livingstone, I presume?’ during his rescue.
Honored with statues, place names, and institutions worldwide.

subsections.title: Death and Memorial
subsections.content: David Livingstone died in 1873 during an expedition in Africa.
points: Passed away in present-day Zambia.
His heart was buried in Africa, while his body was taken to England for burial.
His legacy continues to inspire explorers and humanitarians.

subsections.title: Introduction
subsections.content: The British South Africa Company was a mercantile company chartered in 1889 to promote British interests in southern Africa, mainly in present-day Zimbabwe and Zambia.
points: Founded by Cecil Rhodes to facilitate colonization and economic exploitation.
Operated under a Royal Charter granted by the British government.
Played a significant role in the expansion of British colonial rule in Africa.

subsections.title: Objectives and Activities
subsections.content: BSAC aimed to develop mining, trade, and administration in the territories under its control.
points: Secured mineral rights and land concessions from local chiefs.
Established infrastructure like railways and towns to support mining.
Administered law and order, functioning as a governing authority.
Promoted settlement by European colonists.

subsections.title: Territorial Influence
subsections.content: The company controlled large areas in southern Africa, known as Rhodesia.
points: Northern Rhodesia (now Zambia) and Southern Rhodesia (now Zimbabwe).
Negotiated treaties and conflicts with indigenous groups.
Facilitated British imperial expansion into the interior of Africa.

subsections.title: Legacy and Impact
subsections.content: BSAC's operations had lasting effects on the region’s political, social, and economic landscape.
points: Laid foundations for colonial administration in Rhodesia.
Exploited natural resources, especially minerals like gold and copper.
Contributed to displacement and subjugation of indigenous peoples.
Influenced the region’s demographic and cultural changes.

subsections.title: End of Company Rule
subsections.content: BSAC’s administrative role declined in the mid-20th century.
points: Company administration ended with the establishment of responsible governments.
Northern Rhodesia gained independence as Zambia in 1964.
Southern Rhodesia transitioned to Zimbabwe after independence in 1980.

subsections.title: Definition
subsections.content: The transatlantic slave trade involved the capture and transportation of Africans to work in the Americas.
points: Began in the 15th century and lasted for over 400 years.
Involved European traders and African middlemen.

subsections.title: Impact on Africa
subsections.content: The slave trade severely affected African societies.
points: Millions of Africans were forcibly taken from their homes.
Communities were depopulated and weakened.
Cultural heritage and social structures were disrupted.

subsections.title: Abolition of the Slave Trade
subsections.content: Efforts to end the slave trade began in the 18th century.
points: Led by abolitionists in Europe and America.
Britain banned slave trade in 1807; slavery abolished in British colonies in 1833.

subsections.title: Background
subsections.content: Malawi, formerly Nyasaland, was under British colonial rule.
points: Part of the Federation of Rhodesia and Nyasaland (1953–1963).

subsections.title: Independence Movement
subsections.content: Malawians organized themselves to fight for self-rule.
points: Malawi Congress Party (MCP) was formed to demand independence.
Protests, petitions, and political organization increased pressure on colonial authorities.

subsections.title: Key Leader
subsections.content: Dr. Hastings Kamuzu Banda was the central figure in Malawi’s fight for independence.
points: Returned from abroad in 1958 to lead the movement.
Later became Malawi's first Prime Minister and President.

subsections.title: Independence Achievement
subsections.content: Malawi gained independence on July 6, 1964.
points: The country transitioned to self-governance.
Celebrated annually as Malawi’s Independence Day.
